issues.title: Section 18.3.8 Decline Reply message
issues.author: twintersunh
issues.body:
OLD:
The client includes a Status Code option (see [Section 21.13](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8415# section-21.13))
with the value Success, a Server Identifier option (see [Section 21.3(https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8415#section-21.3)) with the server's DUID, and a Client Identifier option (see [Section 21.2](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8415#section-21.2)) with the client's DUID.
NEW:
The server includes a Status Code option....

comments.author: bevolz
comments.body:
Hi … not sure what or why this was generated, but this was fixed in 8415bis already.- Bernie (from iPad)On Mar 9, 2023, at 9:55 AM, Timothy Winters ***@***.***> wrote:﻿
OLD:
The client includes a Status Code option (see [Section 21.13](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8415# section-21.13))
with the value Success, a Server Identifier option (see [Section 21.3(https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc8415#section-21.3)) with the server's DUID, and a Client Identifier option (see Section 21.2) with the client's DUID.
NEW:
The server includes a Status Code option....

comments.author: twintersunh
comments.body: Already fixed.

pulls.title: various changes (see 1st comment)
pulls.author: tomaszmrugalski
pulls.body:
Here are the changes I'd like to submit:

- RFC7283 to informative reference (was obsoleted by 8415, can't keep it as normative, as idnits treats it as an error)
- added list of deprecated mechanisms in 8415 (there is a similar list for 8415bis)
- typo (gleaming => gleaning)
- added text what to do if IA_TA is received (ignore option, continue message processing)

comments.author: tomaszmrugalski
comments.body: Updated the IA_TA processing as discussed over mail (MUST => SHOULD).

pulls.title: Address further server unicast obsoleting
pulls.author: bevolz
pulls.body:
Hi:

Here's additional changes to address the discussion in the WG regarding removing the UseMulticast status code and more. I likely should confirm on mailing list ... but likely it will be quiet and perhaps best to just ask folks to review. Basic changes are:
- Changed deprecated to obsolete as features are really gone in this specification.
- Obsoleted UseMulticast status code.
- Removed remaining text related to unicast/multicast checks by servers.

I didn't check that XML code is OK, but will do so shortly.

Note: This version uses XML2RFC V3! I didn't create a pull request for that as I used the tool to do this and it resulted in an identical txt version of the document.

comments.author: bevolz
comments.body:
I guess changes ok. Perhaps “the server unicast” should be “the server’s unicast”?- Bernie (from iPad)On Apr 27, 2023, at 4:38 AM, Tomek Mrugalski ***@***.***> wrote:﻿
@tomaszmrugalski commented on this pull request.



In draft-ietf-dhc-rfc8415bis-01.xml:
> -        the Server Unicast option and is upgraded to not support it, may receive a
-        unicast message if it previously sent the client the Server Unicast
-        Option.</t>
-        <t>When the server receives a message via unicast from a client,
-        the server discards that message and responds with an Advertise
-        (when responding to a Solicit message) or Reply message (when
-        responding to any other messages) containing a Status Code option
-        (see <xref target="RFC3315-22.13" format="default"/>) with the
-        value UseMulticast, a Server Identifier option
-        (see <xref target="RFC3315-22.3" format="default"/>) containing the
-        server's DUID, the Client Identifier option
-        (see <xref target="RFC3315-22.2" format="default"/>) from the client
-        message (if any), and no other options.</t>
+        and UseMulticast status code (see <xref target="RFC3315-22.13" format="default"/>)
+        have been obsoleted and hence clients should no longer send the
+        server unicast messages nor receive the UseMulticast status code.

⬇️ Suggested change
-        server unicast messages nor receive the UseMulticast status code.
+        messages sent to the server unicast address nor receive the UseMulticast status code.



—Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or unsubscribe.You are receiving this because you authored the thread.Message ID: ***@***.***>

comments.author: bevolz
comments.body:
We can remove that MUST.For the other change:+        <t>The server is SHOULD NOT accept unicast traffic from aThe “is” should be removed! But personally I would prefer to leave this as it was as using RFC2119 keywords implies that someone could add a conformance test which we don’t want. And it also seems odd to have removed MUST from other section and then add SHOULD NOT here.- Bernie (from iPad)On Jun 8, 2023, at 8:55 AM, Timothy Winters ***@***.***> wrote:﻿
@twintersunh commented on this pull request.



In draft-ietf-dhc-rfc8415bis-01.xml:
> @@ -1789,11 +1790,6 @@
       contain unknown options (or instances of vendor options with unknown
       enterprise-number values). These should be ignored as if they were not
       present.  This is critical to provide for future extensions of DHCP.</t>
-      <t>A server MUST discard any Solicit, Confirm, or Rebind messages

Do we want to remove the discard of Solicit, Confirm, and Rebind which should be Multicast?



In draft-ietf-dhc-rfc8415bis-01.xml:
> @@ -3631,21 +3622,14 @@
         <name>Reception of Unicast Messages</name>
         <t>The server is not supposed to accept unicast traffic from a

⬇️ Suggested change
-        <t>The server is not supposed to accept unicast traffic from a
+        <t>The server is SHOULD NOT accept unicast traffic from a



—Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or unsubscribe.You are receiving this because you authored the thread.Message ID: ***@***.***>

reviews.author: tomaszmrugalski
reviews.body: I've reviewed the changes. Looks good overall, with some minor wordsmithing proposed. I tried to use github's suggestion mechanism. If you like it, you can click approve and those will be applied automatically.

comments.body: I don't like the "server unicast messages". It's ambiguous. Is it "messages with server-unicast option", "messages sent to the server unicast address" or both? We should rephrase. Maybe "messages sent to the server unicast address"?

```suggestion
        and is upgraded to no longer support it, may continue to receive
```

```suggestion
        <t>The Server Unicast option is obsoleted. Please refer to
```

```suggestion
        messages sent to the server unicast address nor receive the UseMulticast status code.
```
Do we want to remove the discard of Solicit, Confirm, and Rebind which should be Multicast?

This text would be broken because of the "the" on line 3626 ("send the messages sent to the server unicast address"). I'm not sure how to adjust the text to fix this in GitHub tool here? I think we should say "and hence clients should no longer send messages to a server's unicast address nor receive the UseMulticast status code."

reviews.author: bevolz
reviews.body: I updated this some - though there is still one issue outstanding as the proposed text is broken. Not sure how to fix this.

pulls.title: Put better makefiles ci

pulls.body: This rebases the document onto the latest MT templates, with github actions to do all the work.

pulls.title: Put better makefiles ci
pulls.author: mcr
pulls.body:
This pull request reparents the repo with the MT template, and imports the -02.xml file (with the document name updated).
This does all the work in github actions, or locally, as you wish.

comments.author: tomaszmrugalski
comments.body: The [CI job](https://github.com/dhcwg/rfc8415bis/actions/runs/5469161480/jobs/9957739455?pr=5) has a step called `Archieve Built Drafts`. It claims to upload them somewhere. Do you know where? Is this a stable, long term storage?

comments.author: bevolz
comments.body:
I also agree that keeping multiple copies is confusing.Well, I obviously like it. Sometimes there’s a need to undo things done in a newer draft and also much easier to fine issues (especially xml related) when you can easily compare to a known “good” copy (i.e., submitted as draft). Tagging does work too but more easily forgotten.Also, if we submit xml version (which is what I’ve been doing), perhaps possible to pull that from datatracker?I understand that it likely messes up automation since file name changes over time as draft progresses.- Bernie (from iPad)On Jul 9, 2023, at 5:10 PM, Tomek Mrugalski ***@***.***> wrote:﻿
@tomaszmrugalski commented on this pull request.



In draft-dhcwg-dhc-rfc8415bis.xml:
> @@ -1,6738 +0,0 @@
-<?xml version="1.0" encoding="US-ASCII"?>

I think you missed my point. I'm OK with removing them, just not the way how you proposed by simply deleting them. This way you'd lose the history of changes, you wouldn't be able to use git blame to find out who committed specific line, etc.
I also agree that keeping multiple copies is confusing. I did apply my changes to wrong file...
I don't have a good answer how to handle this properly, just some vague idea that could possibly work. We could do interactive rebase to rewrite history. We could keep renaming a single file to match whatever filename the next commit wanted to update. At the end, we would have a single file with the changes applied by appropriate authors. It's a bit more work. I can do an experiment some time next week if you feel it's useful.

—Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or unsubscribe.You are receiving this because you were mentioned.Message ID: ***@***.***>

comments.author: mcr
comments.body:
> I think you missed my point. I'm OK with removing them, just not the way how you proposed by simply deleting them.

If you'd like I can go back and commit each of them as .xml and pile them up properly.
I tried to do this when we first started, but got told it wasn't important.

comments.author: mcr
comments.body:
> I also agree that keeping multiple copies is confusing.Well, I obviously like it. Sometimes there’s a need to undo things done in a newer draft and also much easier to fine issues (especially xml related) when you can easily compare to a known “good” copy 

1. Well, 99% of the XML issues go away if you'd let us use kramdown as I originally proposed.  And the formatting of the XML is really really really poor, so no wonder there are problems with debugging xml2rfc issues.  I basically begged you to let me setup the repo properly when we started.

2. Clearly, git and revision control does not suit you.  If you aren't doing a git commit every ~20 minutes, right after you type "make", then you aren't really using revision control. It's just a complicated USB drive.

3. git cat-file HEAD^^^ foo.xml >oldfile.xml

reviews.author: tomaszmrugalski
reviews.body:
Overall, I like most of the changes a lot. Github actions are very useful, the addition of CI pipeline is awesome, the makefile works well for me.

What's probably controversial is the removal of old versions. If you want to go ahead with this, I think the best would be to move it to separate PR and merge the rest of it.

There are some minor nits here and there that should be addressed before merging.

comments.body: I don't know what CODEOWNERS file syntax is, but it claims @mcr and Sheng's mails are incorrect. Should they match what's on your github's account e-mails list?
`/mcr/` => `/dhcwg/`
This merge artifact should be removed.

I agree that keeping copies in git is not a good practice. But I'm against removing them the way it's done here.

In my perfect world, there would be one file with history and specific versions would be tagged.

You might also check up with @bevolz. I recall Bernie was fond of keeping the copies for easier comparison.
It would be updated as soon as the first run of the Editor Copy action was run.
Sure, we can use GIT as a shared zip drive.  But, the extra files distract and confuse.

I think you missed my point. I'm OK with removing them, just not the way how you proposed by simply deleting them. This way you'd lose the history of changes, you wouldn't be able to use `git blame` to find out who committed specific line, etc.

I also agree that keeping multiple copies is confusing. I did apply my changes to wrong file...

I don't have a good answer how to handle this properly, just some vague idea that could possibly work. We could do interactive rebase to rewrite history. We could keep renaming a single file to match whatever filename the next commit wanted to update. At the end, we would have a single file with the changes applied by appropriate authors. It's a bit more work. I can do an experiment some time next week if you feel it's useful.
As @mcr explained, this would be updated as soon as the first run of the Editor Copy action was run.
I've pushed a fix 669f7986f105285ede76d5e3a14a6eba532fb559 that fixes this.

> I think you missed my point. I'm OK with removing them, just not the way how you proposed by simply deleting them. 

I have now merged them into the history.

reviews.author: tomaszmrugalski
reviews.body: There's one tiny [nit in CODEOWNERS](https://github.com/dhcwg/rfc8415bis/pull/5/files#r1255710782), but I'm not sure what to do with it. It's OK to merge if we don't know how to fix it or it's too much hassle.

comments.body:
I don't know anything about this, but that address is what I expect to use for IETF work.
Sheng did leave Huawei, so I think his address is correct.

pulls.title: Implementation report
pulls.author: tomaszmrugalski
pulls.body:
This PR adds an implementation report. This is as far as I could push it before ran out of time. Many of the RFC7942 requests are fulfilled, but some aren't.

Please review.

comments.author: tomaszmrugalski
comments.body:
A question to whoever reviews this: Do we want to mention IPv6 ready phase-2/DHCPv6 tests? It's old (2012), but there's a bunch of extra implementations that are not mentioned above?

https://www.ipv6ready.org/db/index.php/public/search/?l=&c=&ds=&de=&pc=&ap=2&oem=&etc=D&fw=&vn=&do=1&o=6

pulls.title: proposed text dealing with DHCP PD Release
pulls.author: mcr
pulls.body: This paragraph attempts to deal with lifetimes for DHCPv6-PD, with the remainder of the issues dealt with in references.

comments.author: bevolz
comments.body:
I think you meant “address space”?      <t>       A client that has delegated any of the address space received through       DHCP Prefix Delegation MUST NOT issue a DHCP Release on the relevant       delegated prefix while any of the address space is outstanding.       That includes addressed leased out by normal DHCPv6 (IA_NA), prefixes via       DHCPv6-PD (IA_PD), and addresses autoconfigured by IPv6 Router       Advertisements.And “outstanding” on its own here is maybe not clearest? Perhaps something about has been advertised or delegated with a non-zero outstanding valid lifetime?      <t>       A client that has delegated any of the address space received through       DHCP Prefix Delegation MUST NOT issue a DHCP Release on the relevant       delegated prefix while any of the address space has a non-zero
       valid lifetime remaining.       That includes addressed leased out by normal DHCPv6 (IA_NA), prefixes via       DHCPv6-PD (IA_PD), and addresses autoconfigured by IPv6 Router       Advertisements.I’d really prefer referencing the later works as informational too.- Bernie (from iPad)On Aug 21, 2023, at 1:55 PM, Michael Richardson ***@***.***> wrote:﻿This paragraph attempts to deal with lifetimes for DHCPv6-PD, with the remainder of the issues dealt with in references.

reviews.author: bevolz
reviews.body:
Hi:

I think two small edits would improve this and I am ok with the text. One is to use a semicolon instead of period at end of “first” sentence. Second is to change addressed to addresses in last sentence.

         A client that has delegated any of the address space received through
         DHCP Prefix Delegation MUST NOT issue a DHCP Release on the relevant
         delegated prefix while any of the address space is outstanding;
         <xref target="RFC9096" format="default" /> section WPD-9 makes this
         Best Current Practice.
         That includes addresses leased out by normal DHCPv6 (IA_NA), prefixes via
         DHCPv6-PD (IA_PD), and addresses autoconfigured by IPv6 Router
         Advertisements.

comments.author: tomaszmrugalski
comments.body:
Okay, I went through those handful of comments we received so far and added requested references. There's one discussion thread that sort of hung (See [Esko's mail from Nov. 20](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/dhcwg/frlawaPCzBLbVMUAE7-hElg-qBA/). Esko on Nov. 11 he proposed to update 5 items, but once someone (Tim, I think) explained the scope of bis work, he asked:

> If we change text to clarify something, without proposing new functionality, would that still fit in the 8415bis scope or cleaning up, or not?

but he got no answer. In my opinion the list in 18.2.12 is non-normative. I treat it as a non-exhaustive list of examples, so I'm fine if they want to add couple more. He also proposed to donate a text for "significant change", I'd love to get it.

Thoughts?

pulls.title: Clarification of "the significant change" on link
pulls.author: tomaszmrugalski
pulls.body:
This PR is about resolving issues raised during WGLC by Esko Dijk. The [initial proposals](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/dhcwg/BtE7OBvoysnm0kySMYum9EUqEYc/) called for 5 changes:
1. rejected as it would change the normative language.
2. the requirement to send confirm,renew or inf-request needs to be clarified - discussion in progress
3. already applied on this PR
4. the M bit is informative.
5. I would be hesitant to add new normative language to add any extra delays.

I already applied changes proposed by Esko in his Nov. 11 mail regarding 3 (clarify the text significant changes).

comments.author: EskoDijk
comments.body:
Thanks @tomaszmrugalski , building further on my email response to Tim of Nov 17 2023, I'm proposing to add the following item to the bullet list of examples in 18.2.12:

```
* The client’s network interface indicates a disconnection event, followed by a connection event.
```

comments.author: tomaszmrugalski
comments.body:
> I'm proposing to add the following item to the bullet list of examples in 18.2.12:
> 
> ```
> * The client’s network interface indicates a disconnection event, followed by a connection event.
> ```
Thanks for the text. Looks good to me. Added.

comments.author: EskoDijk
comments.body:
@tomaszmrugalski  here below for completeness the updated text for point 2. as I proposed on the list:

OLD: 

If not associated with one of the above-mentioned conditions, a client SHOULD initiate a Renew/Reply exchange (as if the T1 time expired) as described in Section 18.2.4 or an Information-request/Reply exchange as described in Section 18.2.6 if the client detects a significant change regarding the prefixes available on the link (when new prefixes are added or existing prefixes are deprecated), as this may indicate a configuration change. However, a client MUST rate‑limit such attempts to avoid flooding a server with requests when there are link issues (for example, only doing one of these at most every 30 seconds).

NEW:

If not associated with a detection of having moved to a new link, a client SHOULD initiate one of the Renew/Reply, Confirm/Reply or Information-request/Reply exchanges, if the client detects a significant change regarding the prefixes available on the link. A change is considered significant when one or more on-link prefixes are added, and/or one or more existing on-link prefixes are deprecated. The reason for this is that such a significant change may indicate a configuration change at the server. However, a client MUST rate‑limit such exchange attempts to avoid flooding a server with requests when there are link issues (for example, only doing one of these at most every 30 seconds).

The above selection of an exchange to initiate depends on the client's current state:
1. If the client has any valid delegated prefixes obtained from the server, it sends Renew (as if the T1 time expired) as described in Section 18.2.4.
2. Else, if the client obtained address(es) from the server, it sends Confirm as described in Section 18.2.3.
3. Else, if only network information was obtained from the server, it sends Information-request as described in Section 18.2.6.

pulls.title: Updated UDP port text and removed IA Addr requirement to be IA_NA.
pulls.author: twintersunh

comments.author: bevolz
comments.body:
Hi Tim:In general, looks great. However, the new section for IA Address Option:      <section anchor="RFC3315-22.6" numbered="true" toc="default">        <name>IA Address Option</name>        <t>The IA Address option is used to specify an address associated        with an IA_NA. The IAaddr‑options field encapsulates those options that are        specific to this address.</t>        <t>The format of the IA Address option is:</t>Is not necessarily much better as it still ties this option to IA_NA which it isn’t in a Leasequrery nor in the address notification work.I wonder whether the following is better:     <section anchor="RFC3315-22.6" numbered="true" toc="default">
     <name>IA Address Option</name>
     <t>The IA Address option is used to specify an address.
     In this document it is only used encapsulated within an IA_NA.
     The IAaddr options field encapsulates those options that are
     specific to this address.</t>
     <t>The format of the IA Address option is:</t>Or something like that. We could reference that it is used elsewhere in Leasequery (RFC 5007) and the new address notification RFC <to be>, but not sure that is necessary?- Bernie (from iPad)On Jul 5, 2024, at 12:26 PM, Timothy Winters ***@***.***> wrote:﻿



You can view, comment on, or merge this pull request online at:
  https://github.com/dhcwg/rfc8415bis/pull/11

Commit Summary

  4150a23  Updated UDP port text and removed IA Addr requirement to be IA_NA.


File Changes  (1 file)

  
    M
    draft-ietf-dhc-rfc8415bis.xml
    (15)
  


Patch Links:

  https://github.com/dhcwg/rfc8415bis/pull/11.patch
  https://github.com/dhcwg/rfc8415bis/pull/11.diff


—Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or unsubscribe.You are receiving this because your review was requested.Message ID: ***@***.***>

comments.author: bevolz
comments.body:
Oh, and thanks for working on this!

If and when we’re ready to publish, I’m happy to do a final review comparing current published with new.

- Bernie (from iPad)

comments.author: mcr
comments.body: go ahead. Not sure how these other commits wound up in your branch, but whatever.

comments.author: tomaszmrugalski
comments.body: I've reviewed those changes and they look good. I particularly like the port clarification.

comments.author: tomaszmrugalski
comments.body: And thanks for moving forward with this!

comments.author: twintersunh
comments.body: I reverted my bad commit, my apologies for the noise.  I made changes based on Bernie's feedback.

comments.author: bevolz
comments.body:
Hi Tim:Thanks …        The IA Address option is used to specify an address.
        In this document it is only specified to be encapsulated within an
        IA_NA.  DHCPv6 Leasequery <xref target="RFC5007" format="default"/> specifies
        using of the IA Address Option. The IAaddr‑options field encapsulates those
        options that arespecific to this address.

However, a space is missing in “arespecific” and it might be better to say:

        DHCPv6 Leasequery <xref target="RFC5007" format="default"/> makes
        use of the IA Address Option without encapsulating it in IA_NA.- Bernie (from iPad)On Jul 8, 2024, at 2:40 PM, Timothy Winters ***@***.***> wrote:﻿
I reverted my bad commit, my apologies for the noise.  I made changes based on Bernie's feedback.

—Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub, or unsubscribe.You are receiving this because your review was requested.Message ID: ***@***.***>

comments.author: twintersunh
comments.body: Thanks for the quick review Bernie.  Made the changes.

pulls.title: Tim/draft 06
pulls.author: twintersunh
pulls.body:
- Addressed Bernie's comments on 05
- Addressed Document Shepards comments.

pulls.title: Addressing AD comments
pulls.author: tomaszmrugalski
pulls.body:
This PR attempts to address [responsible AD comments](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/dhcwg/DAuBEg10-I3XawzJOvzt2uhxe0o/). Here's the list of edits made:

 - replaces => obsoletes
 - year added to time of writing
 - rephrased weird "normal DHCPv6" expression
 - IA_LL referenced in terminology
 - corrected: addressed => addresses
 - corrected: three cases => two cases
 - one normative MAY added in 18.4
 - clarified what happens if IA_TA or SERVER_UNICAST is still used
 - clarified ignoring unknown options

Remaining items:
- convert ascii drawings to SVG

comments.author: tomaszmrugalski
comments.body: We had a brief discussion among interested parties and @bevolz, @twintersunh, Suresh, @mcr, and me prefer to stick with ASCII art, so I've reverted.
